content: The "Screening Mammography Act of 2005" mandates coverage of annual screening mammography under group health plans, with standards relating to benefits for screening mammography outlined in the Public Health Service Act. The "Screening Mammography Act of 2005" requires group health plans to cover annual screening mammography on terms equal to diagnostic mammography, as defined by medically necessary radiologic procedures for diagnosing breast cancer. The "Screening Mammography Act of 2005" mandates coverage for annual screening mammography by group health plans without denial based on medical necessity or referral by a healthcare provider. The text chunk discusses prohibitions related to health care providers under the Screening Mammography Act of 2005, including denying eligibility based on avoiding plan requirements, providing incentives to accept less protection, penalizing providers for following the Act, and incentivizing providers to provide care in a certain manner. The section clarifies that participants or beneficiaries are not required to undergo annual screening mammography. It also exempts group health plans that do not cover diagnostic mammography and allows for cost-sharing for screening mammography benefits. The section allows for cost-sharing for screening mammography benefits, with coinsurance not exceeding that for diagnostic mammography. Group health plans can require consultation with a healthcare practitioner before more frequent screening mammograms, but prior authorization is not needed for annual screenings. Group health plans must comply with notice requirements and can negotiate reimbursement levels for care provided under this section. The requirements of this section may not apply to health insurance coverage in certain states governed by state laws. Annual screening mammography coverage must be provided by group health plans and health insurance issuers offering group health insurance coverage, with terms not less favorable than those for diagnostic mammography. Diagnostic mammography is defined as a medically necessary radiologic procedure for diagnosing breast cancer, including physician interpretation of results. Annual screening mammography, provided annually for early detection of breast cancer, includes a physician's interpretation of results. Group health plans and insurance issuers cannot deny coverage based on medical necessity or lack of referral. The amendments made by this section apply to group health plans for plan years starting on or after January 1, 2006, except for plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act, which are subject to different effective dates. For plans under collective bargaining agreements, any amendment made to conform to new requirements added by the Act shall not be considered a termination of the agreement. SEC. 3. COVERAGE OF ANNUAL SCREENING MAMMOGRAPHY UNDER INDIVIDUAL HEALTH COVERAGE. Amends Part B of title XXVII of the Public Health Service Act to include standards for benefits related to screening mammography. The provisions of section 2707 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements similar to group health plans. State laws may exempt certain classes of individuals from these requirements. The text discusses State laws regulating coverage for annual screening mammography in the individual health insurance market. It includes a conforming amendment to the Act and specifies the effective date for the amendments. SEC. 4. COVERAGE OF ANNUAL SCREENING MAMMOGRAPHY UNDER MEDICAID. Section 1905(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include coverage for annual screening mammography conducted by certified facilities for early detection of breast cancer. The term 'annual screening mammography' is defined as a radiologic procedure provided to women on an annual basis. The amendments made to the Social Security Act include mandatory coverage for screening mammography for early detection of breast cancer. The effective date for these amendments is January 1, 2006, regardless of final regulations being in place. The State plan for medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act must meet additional requirements imposed by amendments. If State legislation is needed for compliance, the plan will not be considered non-compliant solely for not meeting the requirement before the first day of the first calendar quarter after the State legislature's session. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session.
